While the image upload displayed in Bufferâ€™s composer, calendar, and queue will display in 1:1 format, the post preview to the right of the composer will always show the correct format (4:5).

Creating your Instagram post, reel, or story 

  1. To get started, select your Instagram account on the left-hand side of your dashboard.
  2. Open the composer at the top of your queue.
  3. Choose to schedule your post as a Post, Reel, or Story.

  1. Upload the image(s) or video you want to include in your post. 

Good-to-Knows

  • Videos must be 100 MB or smaller.
  • Instagram creator accounts cannot schedule Instagram stories for automatic publishing. Instead, they'll need to be scheduled as a notification.
  • Instagram carousel can only contain images at this time. Carousel posts do not support mixed media, meaning you will not be able to create a post containing both an image and video or a post containing multiple videos.
  • For Instagram carousel posts (i.e. multiple images in one post), once the first photo is selected, all of the following photos selected will be cropped to the same aspect ratio. For example, if the first photo you select is square (1:1), all of your other images will be cropped to a 1:1 format. This is the same when posting to Instagram natively.
  • If you are trying to schedule an Instagram story with multiple videos or images, you will need to schedule each image or video as a separate story in Buffer.
  • If your image or video falls outside of Instagram's accepted aspect ratio range, it will get scheduled as a notification and will need to be posted manually. Learn more about how to finish publishing using notifications here.
  1. Type in or copy and paste the caption you'd like to use. (Note: to include a caption for a story or music to a reel, youâ€™ll need to schedule it as a notification).
  2. Use the toggle to choose between Automatic (to publish automatically) or Notify Me (to schedule as a notification).
    • Note: If you choose Add Sticker and select a feature that is not supported for automatic posting, such as Music, Tag Product, Text, Link, or Topics we'll switch your post to Notify Me so you'll get a notification and you can finish posting in Instagram. We'll also generate a text box for each Sticker so you can leave yourself a note about what music, text, story links, products or topics you want to add in the Instagram app when you finish publishing your post, reel, or story.

Visit our Using notification based publishing for Instagram guide for a walk-through of how to finish publishing your post once the notification comes to your phone).

  1. Schedule your post using one of our scheduling options and you're done!

âš ï¸ All videos posted to Instagram are now posted under the Reels tab. To also share them to your main feed on Instagram, scroll down in the Buffer composer and make sure "Share to Feed" is toggled on:

How to add a thumbnail to your video

By default, the first frame of the video (0 seconds) will be used as the thumbnail. If you'd like to change your thumbnail, you'll follow these steps:

  1. Once your video has finished uploading, click Edit Thumbnail,
  2. Drag the slider to the position in the video you'd like to use as the cover/thumbnail image.
  3. Click Save.

Adding a location

  • To add locations to your Instagram posts, your Instagram channel will need to be linked to a Facebook Page and you'll need to connect Instagram to Buffer through the linked Facebook Page.
  • Locations are only available for automatic publishing. For posts scheduled as notifications, the location field serves as a placeholder to remind you of the location youâ€™d like to manually add when publishing the post directly in the Instagram app.

If you'd like to add a location to your post or reel, start typing any location name or type the name of a Facebook Page you'd like to point to the location of.

Tagging users in images

User tagging is only available on posts published automatically. Itâ€™s not available for reels or stories.

  1. After uploading an image to your post, click the Tag button on the image.
  2. Click the location on the image youâ€™d like to add a tag, enter the @ handle and then click Add Tag.

  1. A link to the Instagram account will appear on the right hand side. Youâ€™re able to add up to 20 tags on an image for a single image post.
  • For carousel posts, the tagged accounts in the image are carried over for each image in the carousel. When this happens, each image tag is added together for a total. If your draft has more than 20 tags, you may see an error and will need to edit the tags down for the carousel post to successfully publish.
  • Please note: all tags in the first image automatically carry over to all other images in the carousel, counting towards the limit.
  • If you need to remove a tag, click the x icon to the left of it on the right hand side. Once youâ€™ve finished adding your tags, click Save and then continue scheduling your post as normal.

ğŸ“ Notes

  • Due to limitations in Instagram's API, we can't auto-complete the @ handle, and you will need to enter the exact @ handle of the Instagram user youâ€™d like to mention.
  • We would strongly encourage you to check each link on the right-hand side to make sure the correct @ handle has been entered.
  • Posts with tags for private or non-existent users will fail.

â­ï¸ The features below are on our paid plans.

Using Hashtag Manager

Hashtags are a great way to make your posts more discoverable on Instagram. Our Hashtag Manager makes it easy to create and save groups of hashtags so that you can build a library of options, experiment with different variations, and easily reuse your top-performing hashtags. Learn more about how hashtags work in Buffer here.

You can find it by clicking the # symbol in the composer. Then, click Create Hashtag Group to start saving your favorite hashtags!

Scheduling a first comment

â­ï¸ This feature is available on our paid plans for Instagram Professional (Business or Creator) Accounts and LinkedIn accounts. The first comment feature is not available for Facebook, X, Threads, Bluesky, Pinterest, Mastodon, Google Business Profiles, or YouTube Shorts.

If your post or reel is set to be published automatically, you'll also have the option to include a first comment. Adding a first comment is helpful if you want to incorporate any information not ideally shown in your caption. 

All you need to do to ensure a comment publishes at the same time as your post is to type your first comment into the first comment field. That's it! ğŸ‰ You now have a comment in the queue and ready to publish alongside your Instagram caption.

Adding Shop Grid links

If you're using Shop Grid, add the link you'd like to direct users to within the Shop Grid Link field.

Have other questions about scheduling your Instagram content? Reach out to us via hello@buffer.com and we'll be happy to help!

FAQ

Is it possible to hide the number of likes from Instagram posts or reels?

No, at this time, it is not possible to hide the number of likes from your posts while scheduling your content in Buffer. To hide the number of likes on your post, you can view the published post on Instagram and use the Hide Likes feature on the post.

Will Instagram posts sent through Buffer be automatically published to Facebook if I have this setting enabled within Instagram?

Unfortunately, due to API limitations, Instagram posts that are published through Buffer will not automatically publish to Facebook, even if this setting is enabled on your Instagram account. To have an Instagram post automatically publish to Facebook, you would need to create the post directly on Instagram.

Is it possible to move the position of my text or change the font of my Instagram story or reel?

No, it is not possible to move the position of your Instagram text or change the font in Buffer. Due to API limitations, Buffer does not support editing the font or moving the text on the screen for Instagram Reels directly within the app. The preview you see in Buffer is just a guideline so you have an idea of what your text could look like.

To customize the font and position of your text, you'll need to do so within the Instagram app itself. You can schedule your Reel with Buffer using the Notify Me option, and when it's time to post, you'll receive a notification on your phone. You can then open Instagram and add your text, choosing the font and positioning it as you like.

Visit our Using notification based publishing for Instagram guide for a walk-through of how to finish publishing your post once the notification comes to your phone).

articles.title: How many posts can I schedule in advance?
articles.bodyMDX:
How many posts can I schedule in advance?

The plan you subscribe to will determine how many posts you can schedule in advance. See our plans here: Features available on each Buffer plan.

In this article:

  1. Posting limits
  2. Fair Use Policy

Posting limits

The below chart shows how many posts you can have scheduled per channel on each plan (Free, Essentials, and Team).

Plan Scheduled posts per social channel
Free plan 10 per channel, up to 30 total if you have 3 channels connected.
Essentials  5,000
Team Plan 5,000

This is not a daily, weekly, or monthly limit, this is the number of posts you can store in each social channel's queue at any one time.

For example, if you're on the Free plan and you already have 10 posts in one of your queues, you won't be able to add any more until the queue count for that channel is less than 10. Put another way, if you share 1 post per day, you'd be able to schedule up to 10 days in advance on the Free plan.

Here's a quick video explainer on how this works in your account:

It's good to keep in mind that we also have daily posting limits in place for each social network, which you can learn about here: Daily posting limits.

Fair Use Policy

You might notice that our pricing page states that we offer unlimited scheduled posts with a Fair Use policy of 5,000 per channel.

We state that this is unlimited as it's extremely rare for any user to get close to the 5,000 post cap. In fact, to hit that cap, you'd have to schedule 465 posts a week, or 66 posts a day to just one channel. It's so rare that out of the 200,000 social accounts connected to Buffer, only 18 come close to this capâ€”yet still don't reach it.

articles.title: How to avoid being logged out when using the Buffer browser extension in Safari
articles.bodyMDX:
How to avoid being logged out when using the Buffer browser extension in Safari

If you're using Safari and find that you're frequently logged out of Buffer's browser extension, changing your privacy settings can help. Please follow the steps below.

  1. In Safari, click Safari and then Settings.
  2. Select the Privacy tab and then un-check the "Prevent cross-site tracking" box.
  3. Restart Safari and you should be all set!

articles.title: Saving and scheduling draft posts
articles.bodyMDX:
Saving and scheduling draft posts

It's important to capture your creative thoughts (even those partially-developed ones) right when you have them. With Buffer's draft features, you'll be able to save your drafts with or without a pre-scheduled date and time selected. Pretty slick, right?

ğŸ“ Looking for the mobile version? See "Creating, managing, and approving draft posts on the mobile app".

ğŸ“ Working with a team? Visit the Managing and approving draft posts article.

In this article:

  1. Accessing your draft posts
  2. Creating posts from the drafts area
  3. Creating drafts from the composer
  4. Creating drafts from the calendar
  5. Scheduling drafts to multiple social channels at once
  6. FAQ

Accessing your draft posts

You can find the draft posts for each of your social channels by clicking the social channel's name on the left side of your dashboard and then clicking Drafts. Note: if you are using the Calendar view, you will need to click the List view first:

You will also be able to access all of your pre-scheduled drafts from the calendar so that you have a view of your whole social content plan in one place. Note that if you didn't add a time and date to your draft, it would not appear in your calendar. We'll talk more about pre-scheduled drafts below.

Creating drafts from the drafts area

You can create drafts right from the drafts area by typing in the "Create a new draft" composer field. From there, you can save your draft with no date/time specified, or you can pre-schedule the draft by clicking Set Time. Pre-scheduling your draft will not cause it to automatically publish at the date and time you selected unless that draft post is moved to the queue prior to the pre-scheduled date/time. 

When a draft is scheduled and the scheduled time has passed, click Edit on the post and select a new time. Once that's saved, you'll see the Schedule Post option again.

Let's explore other ways to create draft posts. 

Creating drafts from the queue

To start your draft from your queue, click on the blue + New button at the top of your dashboard, then click Post to open the composer. Craft your post.

When finished, if you'd like to store it in the drafts area of your account without specifying a date and time for publishing, click Save as Draft.

Alternatively, if you know the date and time you'd like your draft to eventually publish, you can pre-schedule your post by clicking on the down arrow and choosing Schedule Draft. As a reminder, this will not cause your draft to automatically publish at the date and time you selected unless that draft post is moved to the queue prior to the pre-scheduled date/time. 

Speaking of which, the last action that you'll need to take before the draft is fully scheduled is to have someone with full posting access (this could be you or another member of your Buffer organization) click Add to Queue from within your drafts tab.

Creating drafts from the calendar

If you love the full-context view of the calendar, there's good news: you can schedule and view drafts straight from your calendar view! Let's get into it.

  1. First, you'll click Calendar in the upper left-hand menu from your publishing dashboard.
  2. From there, click on the date and time youâ€™d like to schedule your draft. A composer will pop up and you can start drafting your post.
  3. When finished composing your draft post, click on the Schedule Draft button, and youâ€™ll immediately see your draft populate on your calendar at the date and time you originally selected.

ğŸ“ Scheduling your draft will not cause it to automatically publish at the date and time you selected. Instead, it will preset the date and time for publishing, but will still require a user with full posting access to click Schedule Post from the drafts tab before the post is considered ready to publish. If no date or time is selected for the draft, the draft will show Add to Queue instead. Head here to learn more about adding users and setting up permissions in your organization.

The below screenshot shows what it will look like when scheduling your draft from the calendar. Note that there isn't an option to save your post in this case, because you've already pre-selected a date and time in the calendar. 


Scheduling drafts to multiple social channels at once

Looking at the screenshot above, you can see several social channels selected. When the draft is scheduled (or "saved" if composing your draft from the queue), the draft for each of your social channels will land in their respective drafts tabs.

We share instructions on how to find the draft posts for each of your social channels at the top of this article.

FAQ

Will a draft for one post going to multiple channels be saved as one draft?

No, drafts sent to multiple social channels will be saved as independent drafts within each of those social channels' drafts areas. We share more about this below.

Is it possible to view all of my drafts in one place?

Yes, you can view all of your drafts in one list using the All Channels view. The All Channels view will compile all of your drafts across your channels into one scrollable list that you can also sort by channel or tag. Learn more about How to use the All Channels view in Buffer here.

Will I be able to see the same drafts in both the mobile app and the web app (from my computer)?

Yes! Your drafts will be synced between mobile and the web, so feel free to work freely between the two.

How do I send drafts for approval or approve drafts sent to me?

Collaboration on drafts and approval flows are available on our Team plan, and all posts sent for approval go through your drafts area. You'll learn more about the process to send draft posts for approval and to approve draft posts in this article: Managing and approving draft posts

After a draft is scheduled as a post, can it be reverted back into a draft?

It sure can! You can move any post from your queue back to drafts by clicking on the down-arrow next to the Share Now button and choosing Move to Drafts.

Can I collaborate on drafts with my team?

Yes! Click the speech bubble icon in the upper right corner of the draft (kind of like this: ğŸ’¬) to create a Note. Learn more about Collaborating on content with Notes in Buffer.

Can I upload drafts in bulk?

Yes, you can upload your drafts in bulk to Buffer. Learn more about how bulk uploads work in Buffer here.

How can I reschedule an overdue draft?

If the scheduled time has passed and your draft has not been moved to the queue, your draft will be marked as Overdue. If you'd like to reschedule your draft, you can click the Reschedule button on the draft and then choose a new day and time for your post.

Remember, your scheduled draft will not get published until someone with Full Posting Access clicks Schedule Post to move it to the queue.

articles.title: Why aren't my Instagram posts sending automatically?
articles.bodyMDX:
Why aren't my Instagram posts sending automatically?

Instagram works differently than other social networks, and not all posts can be published automatically. Learn more about this here. If your Instagram posts are not sending automatically, it could be because you have notifications enabled by default or because your posts don't meet the criteria to publish automatically.

In this article:

  1. Your automatic publishing checklist
  2. Where to find posts that didn't publish automatically

Your automatic publishing checklist

There are a few factors that affect whether or not your post is sent out automatically, so we've created this checklist to help you identify any missing pieces and make sure you've got everything in place.

  1. Is your Instagram account set as a personal account? Automatic posting is only available for Instagram professional accounts. To switch your account, click the Switch to a Professional account button at the top of your dashboard:

  2. The "Enable Notifications for all posts" setting should be turned off. If this is turned on, all Instagram posts will be scheduled as notifications.
    1. To check, start by selecting your Instagram account on the left hand side of your dashboard.

    2. Click on the gear icon to open the Instagram channel Settings.

    3. Make sure the General tab is selected. From there, make sure "Enable Notifications by default" is not set to Enabled.
  3. Does your image or video meet the aspect ratio requirements? Instagram only allows us to publish images and videos automatically if they meet the following size requirements.
    • All other posts will be sent to your mobile device as notifications. See our detailed aspect ratio guide for more information.

  Aspect ratio range Aspect ratio range as numerical values
Image Between 4:5 and 1.91:1 Between 0.8 and 1.91
Video Between 4:5 and 16:9 Between 0.8 and 1.78
Reels 9:16 0.56

  1. Is your video longer than 60 seconds, or less than 3 seconds? If so, your post will be scheduled as a notification. Videos must be between 3 and 60 seconds in order to be published automatically.
  2. The same applies to Reels, so if a video is shorter than 5 seconds or longer than 15 minutes, it will be scheduled as a notification 

Whenever you're scheduling a post, we'll let you know if it can't be published automatically. Additionally, posts scheduled as notification will display with a "Notification" in the queue. If you haven't worked with notification based publishing before, here's a great guide to get you started!

Where to find posts that didn't publish automatically

If your post was scheduled as a notification, you will find it in the Sent tab with a notification banner. From here, you can send the post to your mobile device to finish it up in the Instagram app and post it manually. You can also share the post again from this tab.


On mobile
Tap the three dots on the top right hand corner of the post. From there you can either publish your post immediately to Instagram or copy it back into your queue.

On web

On the web version of Buffer, go to the Sent tab, find the post you'd like to share and select Duplicate.

articles.title: Scheduling reposts/retweets
articles.bodyMDX:
Scheduling reposts/retweets

Spacing out your posts is a great way to avoid flooding your X/Twitter feed. Adding reposts to your queue within Buffer allows you to share content from your community and ensures you're still providing great content to your followers, all within your preset schedule.

In this article:

  1. Schedule Repost on a web browser
  2. Schedule Retweet on the mobile app

Schedule repost on a web browser

To schedule reposts on a web browser, you will need to have the Buffer browser extension installed.

  1. Find a post you'd like to repost and click the Buffer icon.


  1. The composer will open on the page, allowing you to add a comment (optional) and then add the post to your queue. Guidance on scheduling options can be found here.

  1. Another quick option to schedule a repost on the web browser is to copy and paste the original post's URL directly into the Buffer composer (as long as the link is unshortened). If needed, add any commentary ahead of the copied/pasted URL and it will show as a quoted repost.

ğŸ“ Troubleshooting

For Safari users: At this time, it is not possible to schedule X/Twitter reposts in Safari, as we are blocked by some of the requirements for the extension. Apologies for any inconvenience!

For other browsers: If you have the Buffer Browser Extension installed and do not see the Buffer icon on posts when you are on X/Twitter, please try the following:

  • Remove the Buffer browser extension from your browser and reinstall it from https://www.buffer.com/extensions/.
  • Check your other browser extensions and VPN, and safelist Buffer where possible. Learn more about Opening Buffer in an incognito or private window, how to safelist Buffer, and using a VPN here.
  • Contact our support team at hello@buffer.com if you still need help.

Schedule reposts on the mobile app

To schedule reposts on the mobile app, you will need to have the Buffer mobile app installed.

  1. Open the X/Twitter app and find a post you'd like to repost. Tap the share icon at the bottom of the post and then tap Share via.
  2. Tap the Buffer icon.
  3. The Buffer app will open, with the repostt already loaded into the composer. Feel free to add a comment to the repost if you'd like to.
  4. Make sure you have your X/Twitter account selected to share the post to, by tapping the + icon at the top of the composer and then tapping your X/Twitter account. You'll then need to tap Done or the back arrow at the top of your screen.
  5. Once you're happy with your repost, tap Share. Guidance on scheduling options can be found here.

articles.title: How do I schedule posts for multiple social channels at the same time?
articles.bodyMDX:
How do I schedule posts for multiple social channels at the same time?

Buffer allows you to easily schedule posts to multiple social channels by clicking the + New button at the top of your dashboard.

You wonâ€™t be able to schedule posts for multiple social channels if you choose a specific time slot in the queue, since those slots are designated for that specific channel and posting schedule.

Click the + New button to open the composer, and then simply click each channel to which you want the post scheduled. As you make your selections, channel avatars will be colored. Channel avatars that are not selected will remain uncolored.

If you have more than four channels connected to Buffer, you'll also see the option to Select All Channels. Use this option to create a post for all channels at one time. (You can use Deselect All Channels to remove all selected all selected channels if you change your mind!).

For guidance on customizing your post for each social network, as well as scheduling options, hop over to the Scheduling posts guide.

ğŸ“ After you've scheduled the posts, they become separate from each other. If you need to make edits or delete the post, you will need to make those changes for each post in each channel queue.

articles.title: How to use Buffer's calendar feature
articles.bodyMDX:
How to use Buffer's calendar feature

Scheduling your posts is now more seamless than ever with our improved calendar feature. Thanks to your feedback, we've evolved our calendar to include more features such as filtering posts, changing your calendar views, and creating new posts, making content planning a breeze!

ğŸ“ Looking for the mobile version of "Using the Buffer calendar feature on mobile"?

In this article:

  1. Navigating to the calendar and choosing your view 
  2. First day of the week preferences
  3. Filtering by social channels
  4. Filtering by post type
  5. Filtering by tag
  6. Creating and editing posts in the calendar 
  7. FAQ

Navigating to the calendar and choosing your view 

You can navigate to your calendar by clicking Calendar in the upper right-hand corner of your publishing dashboard.

From there, you can select your desired view by toggling between Week and Month, so you can visually plan your upcoming posts.

In the month view of Buffer, you can see up to 5,000 posts. If you are scheduling more than 5,000 posts per month, we recommend using the weekly view or filtering by social channel to see all of your posts.

First day of the week preferences

Some people consider Sunday the start of the week and others prefer Monday. You can choose which day of the week appears first in the weekly view of the calendar by changing your Preferences. To do this:

  1. Click the profile icon in the top right corner of the web dashboard.
  2. Select Settings from the dropdown menu.
  3. Select Preferences on the left panel.
  4. Under "Start of Week," choose either Sunday or Monday

Filtering your social channels

One of the cool new features within the calendar is the ability to view and plan your content from one or several of your social channels all at once. Filtering your posts is simple; just click on the All Channels drop-down menu in the taskbar and select or deselect social channels until you've created your desired view.

Filtering by post type

If you prefer to plan your content by type, you can toggle between All Posts, Drafts, Sent Posts, Scheduled Posts, and Pending Approval posts. Just click the All Posts drop-down menu in the taskbar and select which post type you want to view.

Filtering by tag

If you're using our Tags (formerly Campaigns) feature to organize your content, you can also toggle your content by tag. Click on the Tags dropdown menu in the taskbar and select which tag you'd like to view. All posts with that tag will appear in the calendar.

Creating, editing and deleting posts in the calendar

Instead of navigating back to your queue, you can create, edit and delete posts right from the calendar view.

Creating Posts

  1. To get started, click the blue + New button located in the upper right-hand corner of the taskbar, or click on the time and date you'd like to schedule the post.

  1. The composer will display and you can select your desired social channels, create your content, and schedule your post. From there, you'll see your newly created post displayed in the calendar on your specified date.

Editing posts

  1. To update the text or media file of a post, click on the post in the calendar and select the Edit option. This will open a preview of your post, from which you can make the necessary changes and then hit Save.
  2. If you only need to reschedule a post rather than update it, you can easily move the post over to the new date and time using the drag-and-drop option.

Deleting posts

To delete a post, hover over the post, click the three dots, and select the Delete option.

ğŸ“ Notes

  • You need to have Full Posting Access to channels to be able to create posts from the calendar view. 
  • When creating a post from the calendarâ€™s Create Post button, you might notice that any of the social channels that are currently filtered to show in the calendar are preselected in the composer, as well. Make sure to deselect any social channels you donâ€™t want that post to publish to.
  • A quick note on timezones: The calendar will autodetect your current timezone from your browser, which displays in the top taskbar for reference. If your social channel is set to a different timezone than your computer is set to, the post will be reflected in your current timezone, but it will still publish at the correct time. For instance, if my post is scheduled to publish at 5pm on my London account, but I'm in EST, I'll see that post in my calendar is set to publish at 12pm EST (which is 5pm BST, London time). There isn't a way to see the timezone each social channel is set to from the calendar itself.

FAQ

Can I schedule posts for multiple channels at once?

Yes, you can schedule a post for multiple channels by selecting the desired channels in the composer when creating your post.

Can I slide my posts to different time slots in my calendar?

You can reschedule posts from inside the Calendar by dragging & dropping them to the desired new time and date.

Can I share a link to the calendar or subscribe to the calendar?

At this time, it is not possible to share the calendar with others or allow others to subscribe to your calendar. The ability to share your content with stakeholders outside of your team's organization is on our team's radar as something we're exploring soon.

Can I add notes to the calendar?

Currently, we are unable to add notes to the calendar. If you'd like to see us add support for calendar notes in the future, you can upvote this suggestion on our feature request board.

What if my calendar view is empty?

Check your filters and ensure you have the correct week or channels selected. If you are part of a Team plan, make sure you have the correct organization selected.

articles.title: Is it possible to schedule one post to repeat multiple times?
articles.bodyMDX:
Is it possible to schedule one post to repeat multiple times?

This is a question we hear a lot. We know that quite a few of you are looking for this type of functionality. Unfortunately, this is not something that our tool offers, and we'd love to share some of the reasons why.

This article contains the following sections:

  1. How the social networks view duplicate content
  2. What are the exact limitations when it comes to repeating the same content?
  3. What is the best way to share content more than once using Buffer?

How the social networks view duplicate content

A great social media marketing strategy can absolutely include refreshing and repurposing content, but duplicating the exact same message is generally discouraged, and most social networks have a section in their guidelines or terms of service about what constitutes as spam.

For example, in February 2018, X/Twitter announced new guidelines to prevent people from misusing multiple X/Twitter accounts to artificially amplify a message.

We have built our scheduling based on advice from each social network that we're partnered with, and will always strive to maintain strong relationships with each one, by adhering to their policies and building a platform that supports the overall goals of the social media ecosystem.

One of our key goals with the platform we're building, is to give users a greater voice on social media and enable them to share authentic content.

What are the exact limitations when it comes to repeating the same content?

Each post in your queue will only be published once. If you need to share a post multiple times, then you would need to create it multiple times within the queue. However, there are some limitations in terms of duplicating the same content. The exact limitations are:

  • You will not be able to create the exact same post more than once within a 24 hour period.
  • With X's/Twitter's more explicit guidelines, you will not be able to schedule a post for multiple X/Twitter accounts at the same time. In addition, you will not be able to use the Duplicate feature for X/Twitter.

What is the best way to share content more than once using Buffer?

With so much content on social media now, posts can easily get missed and lost in the flow, and we understand that you need to get maximum visibility. We do not discourage reusing the actual content being shared (e.g. product links, blog posts, etc), but where we can, we do not allow the exact same message to be shared repeatedly.

  1. One option is to create separate posts in your queue, but make sure they are well spaced out and ideally using different text and/or media.
  2. Another option is to use the Duplicate feature within the Posts report to re-share a specific post after it's been published. We strongly encourage you to modify the post itself (text, image, video, etc.) before adding it back to your queue.

articles.title: How to duplicate posts in Buffer
articles.bodyMDX:
How to duplicate posts in Buffer

With so much content on social media now, posts can easily get missed and lost in the flow. We understand that you need to get maximum visibility.

The Duplicate feature allows you to add published posts back into your queue to share another time. Due to social networks becoming much stricter on the duplication of content, we recommend using this feature lightly, and making changes to your posts before sharing them multiple times (learn why: Is it possible to schedule one post to repeat multiple times?)

You can reshare a post from either the queue view or the calendar view.

articles.title: Troubleshooting "Whoops! Buffer's servers couldn't be reached" error
articles.bodyMDX:
Troubleshooting "Whoops! Buffer's servers couldn't be reached" error

Are you having trouble with images or videos getting stuck in a "Finishing up" state? Or are you coming across this server error:

Whoops, Buffer's servers couldn't be reached to save the update, sorry about that. Would you be up for trying again?

There are a few different reasons why this may be happening and this article will walk through the steps to troubleshoot the most common causes behind this error. 

In this article:

  1. Ad blockers and pop-up blockers
  2. Browser settings

Ad blockers and pop-up blockers

You will most commonly see these issues if you have an ad blocker or pop-up blocker running in your browser. To test if this is causing the issue, open Buffer in an incognito window, and then try scheduling the post again.

If the issue doesn't occur, it's very likely that the ad blocker or pop-up blocker installed in your browser is causing a conflict. Here are some of the most common ones:

    • Disconnect.me
    • uBlock Origin
    • AdBlock Plus
    • Ghostery
    • Privacy Badger

If there is an ad blocker conflict, we would recommend adding Buffer to your allowed sites for those add-ons and trying again.

Browser settings

Firefox

If you are using a Firefox browser, sometimes the default settings can cause some trouble. To change these settings, please follow these steps:

  1. In Firefox, navigate to the browser menu and choose Options.
  2. Select Privacy & Security.
  3. Within the Enhanced Tracking Protection section, click the Manage Exceptions... button
  4. Add the exception "www.buffer.com".

Chrome

If you're using the Chrome browser, you may have "Enhanced Safe Browsing" enabled, which could cause conflicts with Buffer (in particular, the Buffer browser extension). To change this setting, please follow these steps:

  1. Go to your Google Account.
  2. On the left, select Security.
  3. Scroll to â€œEnhanced Safe Browsing for your Account.â€
  4. Select Manage Enhanced Safe Browsing.
  5. Turn Enhanced Safe Browsing on or off.

If you turn on Enhanced Safe Browsing for your account, Enhanced Safe Browsing in Chrome will also be turned on when:

  • Youâ€™re signed in to Chrome
  • Sync is turned on in Chrome without a custom passphrase

If you turn off Enhanced Safe Browsing in your account:

  • It may take up to 24 hours for this setting change to complete.
  • Google Safe Browsing continues to help protect you from dangerous websites, downloads, and extensions

Further information from Chrome can be found here.

articles.title: Is it possible to remove the "Buffer" stamp from posts published to social networks?
articles.bodyMDX:
Is it possible to remove the "Buffer" stamp from posts published to social networks?

Some posts shared through Buffer will display a source stamp or hashtag that mentions that you used Buffer to share the post. This source stamp is something that is added by the social network and some customers have asked if it's possible to remove the mention of Buffer. Sadly, this is not possible as it's something that these social networks require of all third party apps. This article outlines where you will see these stamps.

In this article:

  1. Facebook Pages
  2. Facebook groups
  3. LinkedIn Pages
  4. TikTok business accounts
  5. Mastodon accounts

Facebook Pages

Posts published to Facebook Pages will display a "Published by Buffer" link with the date and time the post was published. This is only visible to Page admins and will not be visible to your page followers.

Facebook groups

Posts published to Facebook groups will display a "Buffer" link, which is visible to everyone.

Please note, posts published to a Facebook group will appear as being posted by the Facebook member who connected the group to Buffer. Learn more about this here.

LinkedIn Pages

Posts published to LinkedIn Pages will display a "Posted by *name*" link, where *name* would be the person who authorized the connection with Buffer. So, if Angela Smith connected the LinkedIn Page to the Publish account, all posts would display "Posted by Angela Smith". However, this is only visible to Page Admins. Your followers will not see this link.

TikTok business accounts

Videos shared to TikTok will have a #Buffer hashtag that will be pre-filled into the caption. This hashtag can be removed while editing the caption. 

Mastodon accounts

Visible to owner of channel and others; this is a source stamp that is added by the social network. Unfortunately, it's not possible to change or remove this app signature as it's a requirement from the social networks for all third-party apps.

articles.title: How to use the All Channels view in Buffer
articles.bodyMDX:
How to use the All Channels view in Buffer

The All Channels view is an easy and efficient way to see all of your content across multiple channels, in one place. You can view your scheduled posts, drafts, posts waiting for approval, and sent posts all from one dashboard. 
In this article:
  1. Accessing the All Channels view
  2. Filtering by content type
  3. Filtering by channel
  4. Filtering by Tags

ğŸ“ Looking for the mobile version of How to use the All Channels view in Buffer?

Accessing All Channels view

To access the All Channels view, click All Channels in the left sidebar of the Publish dashboard:

Good to Know: The timezone listed in the upper right corner of the All Channels view will always show posts according to your computer's current timezone, regardless of the timezone set for each of your channels.

Filtering by content type

The tabs at the top of the All Channels view allow you to toggle between posts in different states (e.g. draft posts, posts waiting for approval, scheduled posts, and sent posts). This means that you view a list of scheduled posts for all channels at once or you can approve all of your team members posts in one place (vs. having to view each queue individually). 
Queue: Use the Queue tab to see all upcoming posts that have been scheduled. 
Drafts: Use the Drafts tab to see your drafts across your social channels. 
Approvals: Use the Approvals tab to see all posts that need approval.
Sent: Use the Sent tab to see all of your published posts. 

Good to Knows:

  • Failed posts will also appear in the Queue tab. 
  • Expired drafts will also appear in the Drafts tab. 
  • Scheduled drafts will appear in both the Drafts tab and the Queue tab (drafts will be indicated by a banner at the top of each draft). 
  • If a draft has been scheduled, the list in the Drafts tab will be organized with scheduled drafts appearing at the top of the list.

Filtering by channel

If you prefer to narrow down the content by channel(s), you can use the Channels filter to select which channel(s) to view. For example, if you manage the LinkedIn and Facebook pages for multiple clients (Client A, Client B and Client C), you can select Client A's Facebook Page and Instagram account in the dropdown, so youâ€™ll only see content for those channels.

Filtering by Tags

If youâ€™ve organized your content with Tags, you can choose to view your content by tag. To do this, click the Tags filter and select which tags youâ€™d like to view and weâ€™ll display the tagged content for you.

articles.title: Setting posting goals in Buffer
articles.bodyMDX:
Setting posting goals in Buffer

Setting a posting goal for your social media content is a smart strategy to ensure you're consistent, intentional, and effective in reaching your audience. With Buffer, you can set a goal for yourself and quickly track your progress, all from your Publish dashboard!

In this article:

  1. Setting a posting goal
    • Setting a posting goal for new channels
    • Setting a posting goal for existing channels
  1. Tracking your posting goal progress
  2. FAQ

Setting a posting goal

Setting a posting goal for new channels

When you first connect a channel to Buffer, you'll be prompted to set a posting goal for the number of times you'd like to post per week. You can choose between 1 time per week, 3 times per week, or 5 times per week.

If you select a posting goal at this time, we'll create recommended posting times within your posting schedule based on the goal you choose. Learn more about how this works here.


Setting a posting goal for existing channels

If you skipped the process when connecting your channel, you can always go back and set a goal for your channel. This will not replace your existing posting schedule (we will only create a posting schedule for you if you do not have one set up for your channel).

To do this:

  1. From the Publish dashboard, select a channel on the left side of Buffer where you'd like to set a posting goal.
  2. Click + Set a posting goal under the channel name:

  1. In the pop-up that appears, choose a posting frequency that aligns with your goals (1x, 3x, or 5x per week) and select Commit to Posting Goal to save your goal.
  2. Repeat the process for any other channels you'd like.

Tracking your posting goal progress

Once you've selected your goal, you'll see it underneath your channel name so you can easily track your progress. As you post throughout the week, you'll notice the tracker change to reflect the number of posts you've published.


FAQ

When does the posting goal reset?

We track the posting goal on a weekly basis, so the tracker will reset to 0 on the first day of the week according to your day of the week preferences.

Can I change my posting goal later?

Yes, you can modify your posting goal at any time by navigating to the settings for the specific channel.

What is the difference between posting goals and posting times?

A posting goal is a personal target for how often you want to post per week. Posting times are the specific, pre-set time slots when the content in your queue will actually be published. You can set up posting times by creating a posting schedule for each channel.

articles.title: Managing and approving draft posts
articles.bodyMDX:
Managing and approving draft posts

This article outlines how to create, manage, and approve draft posts within Bufferâ€™s Team plan.

â­ï¸ While drafts are available on all plans, approving drafts is only available on our Team plan.

In this article:

  1. Creating draft posts
  2. Managing draft posts
    • Video: Requesting approval on a draft
    • Requesting approval on a draft
    • Reverting approval on a draft
    • Adding a draft to the queue
    • Editing or deleting a draft
  1. Managing approvals
    • Editing and approving draft posts in the Approvals area
    • Moving a post back to the drafts list
  1. FAQ

Creating draft posts

All users with access to social channels, regardless of permissions, are able to create draft posts.

There are a couple of different places you can create draft posts:

  • From any social channelâ€™s queue
  • From any social channelâ€™s drafts tab (shown in the image just below)
  • From the calendar

To understand how to best use drafts, head to this article: Saving and scheduling draft posts

Managing draft posts

Your permission level will dictate which options you have available to you when managing draft posts.

Account owners and users with Full Posting Access are able to edit, delete, and move all drafts to the queue.

Users with Approval Required Access are only able to edit, delete, and request approval on their own drafts.

Video: Requesting approval on a draft

Watch the video below to learn more about how to manage and approve draft posts.

Requesting approval on a draft

As a user with Approval Required Access, you will need to request approval on your draft once you're happy with it. To do so, simply click Request Approval and your draft will be moved to the "Approvals" tab.

ğŸ“ If you are the account owner or a user with Full Posting Access, you will not have the option to request approval on your drafts.

The option to Request Approval will appear in a few places:

  1. You'll see the option to Save and Request Approval in the composer:

  1. Or if you've chosen to Save Draft, you can always choose Request Approval later by heading to the Drafts tab and finding your draft that you want to submit for approval:

Reverting approval on a draft

If you've already requested approval but want to keep working on your draft, you can move it back to the drafts list by clicking Revert Approval Request.

Adding a draft to the queue

As the account owner or a user with Full Posting Access, you can move any draft from the drafts list to the queue even if the user who created the draft has not yet requested approval. If you're ready to schedule the post, you should see one of two options:

  • Clicking Add to Queue means no day and time was selected, so it will get added to the next available queue slot.
  • Clicking Schedule Post means it has a pre-set day and time and will be scheduled at the date and time it was pre-scheduled for.

If a user with Approval Required Access has already requested approval on a post, it will appear in the Approvals tab. Account owners and users with Full Posting Access can review and approve posts there.

Editing or deleting a draft

If you want to make modifications to a draft, click Edit, make any changes you like and then click Save Draft. Likewise, if you'd like to remove a draft completely, click Delete and then Confirm. Remember, the account owner and users with Full Posting Access can edit any drafts, while users with Approval Required Access can only edit their own.

Managing approvals

Feel free to watch the video above, which shows the process for users to request approval on a draft post, as well as the process to approve posts: Requesting Approval and Approving Draft Posts

Draft posts that users with Approval Required Access have requested approval on will appear in the Awaiting Approval tab, where both the account owner and users with Full Posting Access are able to review and approve them.

ğŸ“ If you'd like to receive an email when a new draft is ready to review, click your profile avatar at the top right of your dashboard, followed by My Preferences. From there, select the Notifications tab and toggle the "Collaboration" notification to Enabled.

Editing and approving draft posts in the Approvals area

If you'd like to make modifications to a draft post in the Approvals area, click Edit, make any changes you'd like, and then click Save Draft. When the post is ready, simply click the Approve button on the post.

  • If you see Add to Queue, it means the post doesn't have a pre-set day and time, so it'll get added to the next available timeslot.
  • If you see Schedule Post, there's a day and time set, so it'll get scheduled for the day and time it was pre-scheduled for.

Moving a draft post back to the drafts list

If you'd like to move the post back to the drafts list so that the user can continue to work on it, click Move to Drafts, and the user who created the post will receive an email notification as long as they have their "Collaboration" notifications set to enabled.

Deleting a draft post

If you'd like to remove the post completely, click Delete and then Confirm.

FAQ

Is it possible to see a list of all posts awaiting approval? Can I approve all of my organization's drafts in one place?

Yes, by using our All Channels view, you can access a list of all of your posts that are awaiting approval, making the approvals process super easy and efficient. Learn more about How you can use the All Channels view in Buffer here.

articles.title: Getting started as a user in an organization
articles.bodyMDX:
Getting started as a user in an organization

If you are part of a team and youâ€™ve been invited to Buffer as a user within an organization, this guide can help you get set up and ready to work with the tools and social channels you have been given permission to access.

In this article:

  1. What are "organizations"?
  2. Getting your invitation
  3. Access levels and permissions
  4. Working within your dashboard
    • Switching your organization
    • Scheduling posts in the publishing dashboard
    • Working with drafts
    • Viewing metrics and working with reports in the analytics dashboard
    • Engaging with Instagram and Facebook comments
    • Connecting or refreshing channels
  1. Removing yourself from an organization

What are "organizations"?

As an individual Buffer user, you have your own organization with the ability to add your own personal social channels that only you have access to. You might also be part of another organization as a user with access to that organization's social channels. Learn more about the levels of user permissions below.

Notes

  • You will always access an organizationâ€™s social channels and tools on your own Buffer dashboard and you will never need to log into another Buffer account.
  • You will have access to all of the business features of that organization even if you personally have a different plan. Most users of an organization are personally on a free plan. However, when they switch over to the organization they've been invited to, they'll see access to the features available on their organization's business plan.
  • Missing access to some tools? Learn about adding Buffer tools to your organization.

Getting your invitation

Follow these steps to accept your invitation and get set up in the organization:

  1. Watch for an email invitation

    Once someone adds you to their organization, Buffer sends an email to your provided address with setup instructions.

  2. Create or log in to your Buffer account
    • If you donâ€™t have a Buffer account, follow the email link to create one and set your password.
    • If you already have an account, log in using your existing credentials.

  3. Activate your account and access the organization

    Use the link in the invitation email to activate your account and gain access to the organizationâ€™s tools and channels. If you don't see the organization in your dashboard, you may need to switch organizations.

ğŸ’¡Troubleshooting Tips

Not receiving the invite?

  • Check your inbox, including spam or junk folders.
  • If you still can't find the invitation, contact your organization owner to confirm they entered the correct email address and to possibly resend the invite.

Still need help? Reach out to our team at hello@buffer.com so we can help!

Access levels and permissions

Your organization owner will set up your access to the organization and to social channels. Your access level and permissions are explained below.

ğŸ“ Itâ€™s important to note that even with admin access, you wonâ€™t automatically have access to all channels; you still need to be invited to any channels you should see within each tool. If you have admin access but havenâ€™t been invited to any channels, you wonâ€™t be able to create posts or respond to comments. However, as an admin, you are able to invite yourself to any channel at anytime.

Tool Admin access Full posting access (channel specific) Approval required access (channel specific)
Account settings
  • Connect and manage social channels
  • Invite and manage users
  • Manage subscription and billing (account owner only)
  • Read-only access to channels area
  • Read-only access to channels area
Publishing
  • Dependent on the permissions level granted for that social channel (Full Posting or Approval Required access)
  • Create posts
  • Approve draft posts from other team members
  • Create draft posts
Engagement
  • Dependent on the permissions level granted for that social channel (Full Posting or Approval Required access)

Analytics
  • Viewing metrics
  • Create custom reports
  • View campaigns
  • View metrics
  • View metrics

Working within your dashboard

Switching your organization

Once youâ€™ve accepted your invitation and youâ€™ve set up your account (if you didnâ€™t have one already), you can now see your own individual organization and the new organization by navigating to your account menu. You can switch between the two organizations depending on where youâ€™d like to work.

If you are a member of three or more organizations, you'll see the active organization listed and then you can over over it to see the full list of organizations you belong to. Select an organization from the list to switch.

ğŸ“ Notes

  • If both organizations have the same name (such as the default â€œMy Organizationâ€), you can hover over each organization to see which channels are connected. The owner can rename the organization using this guide.
  • If your organization owner hasnâ€™t set you up with access to any channels yet, youâ€™ll see a message saying they need to grant you access. We suggest contacting the owner and asking them to set up your permissions using this guide.

Scheduling posts in the publishing dashboard

If this is the first time youâ€™ve used Bufferâ€™s publishing tool, we recommend visiting our guide for scheduling posts. If youâ€™ve scheduled posts before, keep in mind that you will have access to many other features with the organizationâ€™s business plan that you may not have used previously if you were on other plans.

Working with drafts

All users with channel permissions are able to create draft posts in the drafts area. The drafts area is great for crafting ideas for posts, as well as creating final posts that you'd like to submit for approval. The option to request approval on drafts, as well as the ability to approve draft posts, will depend on permissions. Learn more on how to create and approve draft posts here.

Viewing metrics and working with reports in the analytics dashboard

All users can view metrics in the dashboards. All admins can view metrics in channels they have permission to access, plus create reports and view campaigns. If this is the first time youâ€™ve used Bufferâ€™s analytics tool, we recommend visiting our guide to Getting started with Buffer's analytics features.

Engaging with Instagram and Facebook comments

Team members with Full Posting access for an Instagram business account or Facebook Page within your Buffer organization can respond to the comments that come into that social channel.

If you or another user in your Buffer organization has Approval Required access for an Instagram business account or a Facebook Page within your Buffer organization, they will not be able to access or respond to the comments that come through to that account.

Connecting or refreshing channels

If you have admin access via the social network itself, you can connect and refresh (reconnect) channels within the organization. Itâ€™s very important to be sure youâ€™re connecting channels in the right organization. You can switch organizations in the account menu as shown above. Follow this guide to learn more about connecting and refreshing channels.

ğŸ“ As an Admin, once you connect a social channel, you will have Full Posting Access to it. 

If you notice that some of the channels you have access to have been locked, this is likely because the owner of the organization downgraded their account. When a plan is downgraded, the account is moved to the Free plan with access to only three social channels and no additional users. This is the reason those channels become locked for you.

In this case, you should chat with the organization owner and see if they had intentionally downgraded the account. Itâ€™s possible they didnâ€™t know that downgrading their account would stop you from being able to access those channels or tools.

Removing yourself from an organization

If you need to be removed from an organization, you can reach out to the organization owner or one of the organization Admins and ask them to remove you from the organization using these steps.

How users work within your organization

Each individual Buffer user has their own organization (where they can connect personal channels that only they have access to), and they can also be part of other organizations as a user with different levels of permissions.

Notes

  • Your users will always access your organizationâ€™s channels on their own Buffer dashboard and they will never need to log into your Buffer account.

ğŸ“ If a user can't find their email invitation, feel free to follow these steps:

Assigning permissions

In order for a channel to appear on a user's Publish dashboard, they must be granted posting permissions for that channel. You can do this on an individual channel basis if they need to post to a few channels or you can use the assign in bulk feature if they need to post to several channels.

  • Assigning permissions in bulk - If the user needs to manage many channels, you can select the star next to each channel and then click the Access Level to choose either Full Posting Access or Approval Required.

Here's a GIF of both processes:

  1. Once you're happy with the permissions they've been granted, click Save Changes and you're all set. Once logged in to their personal Buffer dashboard, user will have access to any of the channels you've invited them to. Learn more in this article: Getting started as a user in an organization.

ğŸ“ Please note, if you're using the tags feature, it's important to know that all users within an organization are able to view all tags within the publishing tool, including all posts belonging to those tags, regardless of whether or not they have access to the channel a post belongs to. Only admins can access tags analytics in the analytics tool.

Removing users

FAQ

Can I change a team member's role or permissions after Iâ€™ve invited them to my organization?

Collaborating on content with Notes

How to use Notes

  • Responding to messages requiring approval: If you already have a draft in the Approvals tab, starting a conversation about updates that require approval is a great way use Notes.
  • Sharing notes on rejected messages: If youâ€™ve rejected a post that was awaiting approval, you can use Notes to share more context.

Creating a Note

FAQ

articles.title: Using Buffer as an agency
articles.bodyMDX:
Using Buffer as an agency

Buffer is suitable for agencies, and there are many agency teams that use Buffer! Because all companies are unique, we thought this article could be a place for our agency customers to understand more about how the different tools and features within Buffer could set them up for success. 

In this article:

  1. A few features you might enjoy
  2. Plans and pricing
  3. Connecting your clients' channels
    • Option 1: You (the account owner) connect all social channels
    • Option 2: Your client connects each of their social channels
  4. Giving your clients and staff the right permission levels
  5. Managing draft approvals from clients as an account owner

A few features you might enjoy

There are a lot of fun features to dig into as you get started with Buffer. These are a few that are especially helpful for agency teams.

  • Start Page: Is one of your clients running a seasonal sale or campaign? You can surprise them by creating a beautiful landing page that features their most important links and calls to action. You can learn more about Start Page here: Using Start Page with Buffer.
  • Hashtag manager: Do you have a unique set of hashtags you use for each client or each social channel? The hashtag manager found in your Instagram composer allows you to customize multiple hashtag groups so that you can spend more time creating new posts and less time typing out hashtags. Click here to learn more about the hashtag manager feature: Using Buffer's hashtag manager.
  • Engagement dashboard: It can take hours to get through comments for multiple clients. Your engagement dashboard serves up not only all comments made to each of your clients' Facebook and Instagram accounts, but it also highlights the comments that seem to be most urgent. Learn more about engaging with Facebook and Instagram comments here.
  • Custom analytics reports: Found in your analytics dashboard under "Reports," you have the ability to compile PDF reports showcasing your client's logo and top results. This article shares more about creating custom analytics reports. If you'd rather look at your data more granularly, feel free to download a CSV file or image of that individual chart or graph within any one of your "Channels" views.

Plans and pricing

Agencies tend to connect more channels, analyze more metrics, and create more reports than other customers. So, which plan will be best for you?

  • If you need access for only one user, we recommend the Essentials plan.
  • If you have one or more people collaborating with you in Buffer and/or are looking for exportable, self-branded reports, our Team plan would be the best choice.

Learn more about our plans and pricing here.

What counts as a channel? A channel is each individual Page, group, or profile that youâ€™d like to connect. As an example, you might be scheduling posts for 10 clients who each have five social channels (e.g. Facebook Page, Instagram account, 2 LinkedIn Pages, and Pinterest profile). This would come to 50 channels in total.

Connecting your clients' channels

There are two ways you can get your clientsâ€™ social channels set up in Buffer:

  • You (the account owner) can connect them, or
  • Your client can connect them if they are designated as an Admin on your Buffer account. See below for important considerations with this option.

Letâ€™s chat about both of these options below so that you can make the best choice for your organization.

Option 1: You (the account owner) connect all social channels

To connect all of your clientsâ€™ social channels, youâ€™ll need to have admin permissions or login credentials for each of the social channels that need to be connected.

Each social network is a little different, and the table below shares more about what is involved in obtaining admin access for each of the social networks Buffer integrates with.

Facebook Page Your personal Facebook profile must be an admin on the Facebook Page. Learn more about connecting your Facebook Page to Buffer.
Facebook group Your personal Facebook profile will need to be an admin on the group. Learn about connecting Facebook groups and troubleshooting connections.
Instagram business account

Client's login details (username and password) to connect the channel to Buffer and publish via notifications.

To use Analyze & Engage, you'll also need login details for your personal Facebook profile that has Admin permissions on the Page associated to the Instagram account so you can authorize Instagram to Buffer via the linked Facebook page.
X/Twitter profile Clientâ€™s login details (username and password).
LinkedIn Page Your personal LinkedIn profile will need to have Super Admin access to the Page. Learn more about using LinkedIn with Buffer.
LinkedIn profile Clientâ€™s login details (username and password).
Pinterest board Clientâ€™s login details (username and password).
Google Business Profile Your Google account must be added as a Manager of the Google Business Profile.
TikTok Clientâ€™s login details (username and password).
YouTube Client's login details (username and password).
Mastodon Client's login details (username and password).
Bluesky Client's login details (username and password).

When it comes to connecting multiple Instagram accounts, we do not recommend managing more than 5 Instagram accounts in total and we also recommend each Instagram account be connected to an authentic, active Facebook page. There are several considerations and reasons for these recommendations, which you can read in our Instagram best practices.

Option 2: Your client connects each of their social channels

While itâ€™s possible for users on your account that are designated with the Admin permission to connect their own social channels, there are two important considerations to keep in mind if you decide to go this route:

  1. Admins have the ability to manage any social channel connected to your Buffer organization.
  2. Admins will be able to access the billing settings on the billing page (https://account.buffer.com/billing).

If the other social channels connected to your Buffer organization are confidential (such as if you have many clients and donâ€™t want each to have access to one anotherâ€™s social channels), or you do not want your client to have access to the billing page of your account, youâ€™ll want to move forward with the first option to connect social channels explained above.

Giving your clients and staff the right permission levels

There are four main permissions available on your Buffer plan:

  • Organization owner/Account owner
  • Admin
  • Full posting access (channel specific)
  • Approval required access (channel specific)

Letâ€™s talk about when using each might be most advantageous. To see a broader explanation of all of these permissions, head to the article: Adding users and setting up permissions in your organization.

Organization owner:

The person who has access to the email address and password that the billing is under is the organization owner. There isnâ€™t a way to designate a second owner, but we can transfer ownership to another Buffer user if needed.

The organization owner will always have Full Posting access on all channels and this cannot be changed. You can read more about Full Posting access below.

If you as the organization owner need to submit posts for approval to a client, you might consider creating a different Buffer account with a different email address and invite that user to have Admin access of the organization, but Approval Required access on the social channels youâ€™ll need to submit for approval. With this solution, you will need to login under your owner account to access your billing information, but you should be able to do most other tasks via your new user account, such as create posts, manage users, customize posting schedules, and connect new channels (just make sure to select the correct organization).

Admin:

This permission affects access to your entire Buffer organization. Youâ€™ll give admin permission to anyone on your team who youâ€™d like to have a full range of access, including connecting and removing social channels, creating and printing reports, viewing posting tag success, replying to all incoming Facebook and Instagram comments, and posting to all social channels connected to your Buffer account.

Full Posting access:

This permission affects access to individual social channels. Many agencies set their clients up with Full Posting access on one or more of their social channels. This allows them to add posts, delete posts, assign posts to specific tags, and approve posts drafts on that specific social channel. You can also set your own team members up with Full Posting access for any social channel they have permission to create posts for. Users with Full Posting access can view analytics for those social channels, as well as respond to the comments made on the posts of those social channels (for Facebook and Instagram).

Approval Required access:

This permission affects access to individual social channels. If you donâ€™t want your clients or team members to add posts to the active queue of a specific social channel, but instead would like them to draft posts that you can review before they are scheduled to publish, setting them up with Approval Required access for that social channel is a great move. Users with Approval Required access can view analytics, but cannot respond to the comments made on the posts of those social channels.

What if my client needs to approve the posts my agency creates?

If posts need approval from clients, youâ€˜ll set your staff up with Approval Required access and your clients with Full Posting access for the social channels theyâ€™ll be working on. From there, the flow would be for your staff to create posts within the drafts area and then request approval. The client will be able to review, edit, and approve those posts, at which point theyâ€™ll be moved to the active queue. Learn more about managing and approving draft posts, and make sure to revisit the â€œOrganization ownerâ€ section just above.

 ğŸ“ Good-to-knows

    • If your staff members have Approval Required access on a social channel, all posts they add to that social channelâ€™s drafts area will need to be approved by the client. It is not possible to pick and choose which posts require approval.
    • If your staff members have Approval Required access, they wonâ€™t have the ability to customize that channel's posting schedule, modify any posts in the queue, rearrange the order in which theyâ€™ll be sent, or configure custom publishing times for posts that are already scheduled. These actions need to be completed by the organization owner, the client, or anyone else with Full Posting access.
    • At this time, all users within an organization are able to view all posts added to all tags via the publishing dashboard (https://publish.buffer.com/tags). This includes posts belonging to social channels that the user does not have Full Posting access or Approval Required access to. Without the appropriate permissions, however, the user will not be able to edit those posts, create posts, or access the queue for that channel. The only access they have is to view which posts are associated with which tags.
    • To change the order your channels appear in the channel menu, you can drag and drop into your desired order by clicking on a channel, moving it with your mouse, and then releasing it.

Managing draft approvals from clients as an account owner

Creating another profile to have your drafts approved

As the owner of the Buffer organization, your Buffer account has permanent Full Posting access, meaning that any posts you create will be added to the queue and can't be sent for approval. So as a workaround, you can create another Buffer account for yourself with a separate email address and create your drafts to be approved when signed into that user profile.

To see how this can work, watch the video below to see this in action:

Using the drafts or create area

Set up a cadence with your client (eg: every Monday) to look at the drafts area or create area to review the new posts you've created. Your client can then leave comments on the posts, approve them, or ask for revision. Learn more about creating ideas with Buffer and creating posts from the drafts area.

Adding Buffer tools to your organization

How do organizations work with tools?

articles.title: LinkedIn Page metric descriptions
articles.bodyMDX:
LinkedIn Page metric descriptions

When you connect your LinkedIn Page to Analyze, we will backfill the page data for the last six months and native post data for the previous 30 days.

In this article:

  1. LinkedIn Page metrics in Analyze
  2. FAQ

LinkedIn Page metrics in Analyze

The table below provides a description of each metric that appears within Buffer's analytics.

Posts The number of posts sent.
Impressions The number of times people saw your posts.
Clicks The number of clicks your posts received. This includes the number of clicks on your content, company name, or logo by a (signed in) member. It doesn't include interactions (shares, reactions, and comments)
Likes The number of likes your posts received. You could have a negative number of likes for a day if there are more people who removed their likes than people who liked your posts.
Comments The number of comments on your posts. You could have a negative number of comments for a day if there are more people who removed their comments than people who commented your posts.
Shares The number of times your posts were shared.
Engagements The number of organic clicks, likes, comments, and shares.
Engagement Rate The percentage of impressions that resulted in an engagement (number of engagements divided by the number of impressions). This could be negative if you have a negative number of likes or comments.
Page views The number of views received by your LinkedIn Page.
Followers / Total Followers The total number of followers of your LinkedIn Page.
New Followers The number of followers you gained or lost.
  • Looking for basic post metrics instead? Check out our guide to Insights on sent posts within the Publish dashboard.
  • Seeing conflicting information? Checkout the article: Why your data in Buffer might differ from your native analytics

FAQ

Why can't I see my LinkedIn profile metrics in Analyze?

Analyze does not support LinkedIn personal profiles at this time. However, you can view sent post metrics for LinkedIn personal profiles within the Sent tab of the Publish dashboard.

Can you pull in metrics for LinkedIn sponsored posts within Analyze?

Yes, we are able to pull in metrics for LinkedIn sponsored posts.

Can you pull in metrics for LinkedIn reposts into Analyze?

No, unfortunately, we are unable to pull in metrics for LinkedIn reposts at this time.

How often does the data refresh?

We update our data every 24 hours.

Buffer's analytics dashboard also shows you insights for boosted Facebook posts or promoted Instagram posts. Learn tips on which posts to boost and how to best measure your results in our blog post here!

FAQ

Are native posts included in the Sent tab?

Weâ€™re able to pull in native posts for Facebook, Instagram, Mastodon, Pinterest, and LinkedIn Pages for Free customers.

How far back does the data go?

  • Please note that we'll show posts that have been sent since you added your social channel to Buffer.

Will deleted posts still appear in the Sent tab?

Yes. The Sent tab is a record of all posts sent through Buffer, so a post will still appear in the Sent tab even if the published post has been deleted on the social network.

Is it possible to view all of my published posts in one view?

Yes, you can view all of your published posts in one list using the All Channels view. Learn more about How to use the All Channels view in Buffer here.

How can I delete or edit a published post?

At this time, we are unable to edit or delete a post once it's been published through Buffer. Instead, you'll need to edit or delete the published post directly on the social network. You can find a history of your published posts within the Sent tab of the Publish dashboard.

Why are the analytics for my sent post showing as dashes or zero?

It may take some time for analytics data to sync and appear. If it persists, ensure your channel is properly connected and authenticated.

Yes, posts in the Sent tab include information on which user created the post and when.
